facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Patna High Court judgment dated January 21, 1957 in Criminal Appeal No. 34 of 1956.

facts.text: 22 accused persons including appellant Galfu Sah tried by Assistant Sessions Judge of Darbhanga for offences under Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The short facts are these. Some 22 accused persons, of whom the appellant was one, were tried by the learned Assistant Sessions Judge of Darbhanga for various

facts.text: Incident occurred on May 16, 1954 in village Dharhara, district Darbhanga.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case was that on May 16, 1954, in village Dharhara in the district of Darbbanga a, mob of about 40-50 persons, including the accused

facts.text: Mob of 40-50 persons including accused formed unlawful assembly with common objects to dismantle hut of Mst. Rasmani, set fire to it, and commit assault if resisted.

facts.text: Tetar Mian, chaukidar of village Dharhara, came to village at about 10 a.m. on May 16, 1954 to ascertain births and deaths.

anchor.surface_text: One Tetar Mian, who was the chaukidar of village Dharhara, had companye to the village at about 10 a.m. to ascertain births and deaths for the purpose of supplying

facts.text: Mst. Rasmani was the widow of Ganpat.

anchor.surface_text: near the hut of Mst. Rasmani, who was the widow of one Ganpat, he found the mob engaged in dismantling the hut.

facts.text: Chaukidar Tetar Mian found mob dismantling hut of Mst. Rasmani and protested.

anchor.surface_text: he found the mob engaged in dismantling the hut. The chaukidar protested. On this, it was alleged, the appellant hit him with a lathi on the left high.

facts.text: Appellant hit chaukidar Tetar Mian with lathi on left thigh.

anchor.surface_text: the hut and the hut was burnt. Some members of the mob chased Ramji and Nebi and assaulted them.

facts.text: Supreme Court held conviction under s. 436/109 IPC not bad in law and dismissed appeal.

issues.text: Whether the conviction of the appellant Galfu Sah under section 436 read with section 109 of the Indian Penal Code is correct and the sentence passed thereunder is proper?

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is limited to a particular question only, namely, companyrectness of the companyviction of the appellant Galfu Sah for an offence under s. 436 read with s. 109, Indian Penal Code, and the propriety of the sentence passed thereunder.

issues.text: Whether the evidence on which the conviction of the appellant is based should be disbelieved because the same evidence was disbelieved with regard to the principal offender Budi Sah?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. P. K. Chatterjee has appeared on behalf of the appellant and has contested the correctness of the conviction on two grounds firstly, he has submitted that the evidence on which the conviction was based is the same evidence which was given against Budi Sah, and if that evidence was disbelieved with regard to Budi Sah,

issues.text: Whether the offence under section 436 IPC was committed in consequence of the abetment by the appellant under section 109 IPC, even though the alleged principal offender Budi was acquitted?

anchor.surface_text: secondly, he has submitted that though he does not wish to contend that in every case where the principal offender has been acquitted of the offence, a person said to have abetted the commission of the offence must also be acquitted, there is no evidence in this particular case that whoever set fire to the hut of Mst. Rasmani did so in consequence of the order of the appellant,

issues.text: Whether an abettor can be convicted under section 109 IPC if the act abetted is committed in consequence of the abetment, notwithstanding acquittal of the principal offender?

arguments.claim: The evidence on which the conviction of the appellant is based is the same as that disbelieved against Budi Sah and therefore should be disbelieved against the appellant

anchor.surface_text: Mr. P. K. court_response_anchor.surface_text: ge expressly said that the evidence of the aforesaid four witnesses was companysistent against the appellant. We see numberviolation of any rule of la

arguments.court_reasoning: Evidence had specific infirmities regarding Budi not present for appellant; testimony consistent against appellant; no violation of law or prudence

arguments.claim: There is no evidence that the hut was set on fire in consequence of the appellant's order, even assuming he gave the order, so conviction for abetment bad in law

anchor.surface_text: secondly, he has submitted that though he does not wish to contend that in every case where the principal offender has been acquitted of the offence, a person said to have abetted the commission of the offence must also be acquitted, there is no evidence in this particular case that whoever set fire to the hut of Mst. Rasmani did so in consequence of the order of the appellant,

arguments.qualifiers: though he does not wish to contend that in every case where the principal offender has been acquitted the abettor must also be acquitted
arguments.court_reasoning: Findings show appellant ordered and hut set fire by assembly member in consequence; unreal to say independent of order

arguments.claim: Evidence against Budi unreliable due to omissions in first information and statements, but reliable and consistent against appellant

anchor.surface_text: As to the first point, the learned Judge has in his judgment given good reasons why the evidence of the witnesses with regard to Budi Sah was not accepted and why the testimony of the same witnesses was accepted with regard to the appellant. The witnesses on this point were four persons, namely, Tetar, Ramji, Nebi and Munga Lal.

arguments.claim: Appellant gave order to set fire and hut was actually set on fire by a member of the unlawful assembly

anchor.surface_text: It must be emphasised here that the learned Judge was satisfied that 1 the appellant gave the order to set fire to the hut and 2 tha the hut was actually set fire to by one member or another of the unlawful assembly, even though the unlawful assembly as a whole did not have any common object of setting fire to the hut of Mst. Rasmani.

arguments.claim: Person who set fire did so in consequence of appellant's instigation as per sections 107, 108, 109 IPC

General rule no abetment conviction if principal offence not proved has exceptions where evidence shows offence committed in consequence of abetment, as in Umadasi Dasi v. Emperor distinguishing Raja Khan v. Emperor
Conviction under s.436/109 IPC not bad in law

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the conviction of the appellant for the offence under s. 436 read with s. 109, Indian Penal Code, is not bad in law.

arguments.claim: Evidence against Budi unsatisfactory so acquit under s.436 IPC

Rasmani was not very satisfactory and he acquitted Budi of the charge under s. 436, Indian Penal Code.

arguments.claim: Sentence of 4 years RI not excessive

anchor.surface_text: As to the sentence it does not appear to us that it errs on the side of severity. It has been stated that the appellant was released on bail on serving out the sentence passed against him for the offences under ss. 147 and 323, Indian Penal Code.

holdings.text: the conviction of the appellant for the offence under s. 436 read with s. 109, Indian Penal Code, is not bad in law

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the conviction of the appellant for the offence under s. 436 read with s. 109, Indian Penal Code, is not bad in law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence proves appellant instigated arson and offence committed in consequence by assembly member; exception to general rule on principal acquittal applies per Umadasi Dasi

holdings.text: the sentence ... does not appear to us that it errs on the side of severity

anchor.surface_text: As to the sentence it does not appear to us that it errs on the side of severity. It has been stated that the appellant was released on bail on serving out the sentence passed against him for the offences under ss. 147 and 323, Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sentence of 4 years RI proportionate given offence gravity and concurrent sentences served

holdings.text: no violation of any rule of law nor even of prudence in the learned Judge accepting the testimony of some of the witnesses against the appellant, though he did not accept that testimony against Budi Sah

anchor.surface_text: We see no violation of any rule of law nor even of prudence in the learned Judge accepting the testimony of some of the witnesses against the appellant, though he did not accept that testimony against Budi Sah.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific infirmities in evidence re Budi (omissions in FIR/statements) absent for appellant; consistent testimony against appellant

holdings.text: the person who set fire to the hut of Mst. Rasmani must be one of the persons who were members of the unlawful assembly and he must have done so in consequence of the order of the present appellant

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us, on the findings given in the case, that the person who set fire to the hut of Mst. Rasmani must be one of the persons who were members of the unlawful assembly and he must have done so in consequence of the order of the present appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower court findings confirm order given and hut burnt by assembly member; unrealistic to view act independent of instigation

holdings.text: in the majority of cases the aforesaid general statement might hold good but there are exceptions to the general rule, particularly when there is evidence which satisfactorily establishes that the offence abetted is committed and is committed in consequence of the abetment
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Raja Khan general rule; follows Umadasi exception where independent evidence proves commission in consequence of abetment
